answers: The Line of Beauty (by Alan Hollinghurst)
Margaret Thatcher [or Margaret Hilda Thatcher; accept Margaret Hilda Roberts]
Hilary Mantel [or Hilary Mary Mantel; accept Hilary Mary Thompson]
parts: Name this novel in which Nick Guest navigates his life as a gay man living with the conservative Fedden family.

In The Line of Beauty, a coked-out Nick dances with this Prime Minister at an anniversary party. In a controversial short story, an IRA member proclaims, “fucking rejoice!” before assassinating this “Iron Lady.”

“The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher” appears in a recent short story collection by this author. This author’s novel The Mirror and the Light concluded her monumental trilogy about the life of Thomas Cromwell.

answers: Staphylococcus [accept Staphylococcus aureus or Staphylococcus epidermidis; prompt on S. aureus or S. epidermidis]
Vibrio fischeri [or V. fischeri; accept Aliivibrio fischeri or A. fischeri]
parts: Name this compound that may be iodized for human consumption. Extremophiles that thrive in regions with high concentrations of this ionic compound are called halophiles.

One species in this bacterial genus turns a pink medium that contains mannitol and a high salt concentration yellow. That species of this genus is coagulase-positive, while another member that colonizes the skin is not.

This bacteria, which colonizes the bobtail squid, is also typically cultured in salt-containing media. The lux operon system of this bacteria serves as a model for studies of quorum sensing and bioluminescence.

answers: Methodism [or Methodists; accept African Methodist Episcopal Church or AME]
Lee [accept Jarena Lee; accept Mother Ann Lee]
parts: Name this Protestant denomination that became the largest in the United States due to the efforts of circuit riders during the Second Great Awakening. This denomination was founded on the teachings of John Wesley.
After he gained his freedom and was ordained by Francis Asbury, Allen inaugurated the first independent black church in America, the African Methodist Episcopal Church, in this city in 1794.

Allen’s church sponsored the preaching of Jarena, a woman with this surname, who traveled nearly 2,000 miles per year. Another woman with this surname led the founding of the first Shaker community in America.

answers: concerto grosso [prompt on concerto] (The unnamed subgenre is da chiesa.)
Christmas [accept Christmas Concerto or Concerto “For the Eve of Christmas” or Concerto “Fatto per la notte di Natale;” accept Christmas Oratorio]
parts: Name this genre, which includes a piece that opens with marcato B-flat minor and F-sharp diminished chords before a cello starts its G-minor grave (“GRAH-veh”) first movement. A ripieno accompanies pieces in this genre.

Pietro Ottoboni commissioned that Corelli concerto grosso “for the eve of” this holiday. J.S. Bach’s Ascension and Easter oratorios are grouped with an oratorio for this holiday that is associated with carols like “Silent Night.”

Corelli rocks the Infant Jesus to sleep in the last movement of his Christmas Concerto, written in this style ad libitum. In all Christmas concerti, an obligatory movement in this style evokes country shepherds playing the zampogna and pif ero.

Name this thinker. His book On the Plurality of Worlds argues that, because it is incredibly theoretically fruitful to do so, we should take all possible worlds to be real in the same way as our “actual” world.

One objection to modal realism holds that, as in set theory, one of these situations arises when we imagine a possible world that contains all others. A “liar’s” one of these things arises from the statement “this sentence is false.”

The final chapter of On the Plurality of Worlds advances this view, which is analogous to perdurantism. This view holds that individuals exist in only one world, and are thus not identical with beings in any other world.

answers: Argentina [or Argentine Republic or República Argentina] (The story in the lead-in is “The End” by Borges.)
Ocampo [accept Victoria Ocampo or Silvina Ocampo]
parts: Name this epic poem by José Hernández about the adventures of the title gaucho, who engages in payadas and kills a Black man in a knife fight.
Martín Fierro is set in this country. The short story “El Sur,” which parodied this country’s gaucho lifestyle, was written by its native author Jorge Luis Borges.

Borges’s story “El Sur” shares its name with a magazine published by an Argentine author with this surname. Another author with this surname was the only female editor of an anthology called The Book of Fantasy.
Name these extremely dense astronomical objects which are formed from supergiant stars that fall below the TOV limit and thus don’t form black holes.

Jocelyn Bell initially discovered pulsars while studying this segment of the electromagnetic spectrum. A device designed to observe this segment of the electromagnetic spectrum collapsed in December 2020.

A 2018 study by Zhang et al. proposed that the collapse of a strange neutron star’s crust could cause these radio phenomena. Duncan Laurier discovered these transient pulses of unknown origin while analyzing pulsar data.

answers: Iris Chang [or Chang Shun-Ru] (The other work is The Rape of Nanking: The Forgotten Holocaust of World War II.)
parts: The Yán'ān Rectification Movement followed this event, during which partisans regrouped in Shaanxi province. Edgar Snow drew upon his experience in this event to publish Red Star Over China.

Snow based his magnum opus on numerous interviews with this leader. After Qián Xuésēn was deported during the Second Red Scare, this first Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party employed him as the head of China’s space program.

This historian detailed Qián Xuésēn’s role in the development of the Chinese space program in Thread of the Silkworm. In another work, this historian criticized Iwane Matsui’s role in a “forgotten holocaust.”

answers: traditional ecological knowledge [accept traditional environmental knowledge; prompt on TEK]
parts: Give this three-word term used by anthropologists like Berkes, Darrell Posey, and Robin Wall Kimmerer to describe accumulated indigenous bodies of thought about resource management and local biodiversity.

Berkes describes how the Cree vary their equipment to manage this resource, which is farmed alongside rice throughout Southeast Asia. The Sámi collaborated with the Finnish government to manage declines in this resource.
Another key example of traditional ecological knowledge is the periodic renewal of landscapes using this technology. The use of this technology is alternated with “slashing” in jhum agriculture.

answers: housing complexes [or public housing projects or apartment buildings; prompt on Habitat 67]
parts: Name these projects. Schütte-Lihotsky worked on one of them spearheaded by Ernst May in Frankfurt. Moshe Safdie used concrete blocks for another of these projects built for Expo 67 in Montreal.

In a fire station for this city, Susana Torre designed individual bedrooms in an attempt to shift bonding toward the kitchen and include women socially. Robert Venturi also designed a Modernist firehouse for this Indiana city.

This architect left the kitchen visible from dining spaces, as opposed to hidden away, in his open floor plan for the Usonian Willey House. This architect integrated a waterfall into his Fallingwater.

answers: libraries [or bibliotheca or bibliotheke; accept Library of Alexandria or Bibliotheca Alexandrina; accept Bibliotheca historica or Historical Library; prompt on Musaeum of Alexandria or Mouseion of Alexandria]
Erythraean Sea [accept On the Erythraean Sea or Peri tē̂s Erythrâs Thalássēs; accept Periplus of the Erythraean Sea or Períplous tē̂s Erythrâs Thalássēs or Periplus Maris Erythraei]
parts: Name this metal that was mined south of Egypt according to Diodorus Siculus’s magnum opus. The Lydians heated alloys found in the Pactolus River with salt and brick dust to purify this metal via cementation.
Diodorus’s wide-ranging world history shares a title with these places. Ptolemy I Soter established one of these places in Alexandria that housed a large collection of papyrus scrolls.

Diodorus rehashed many observations made by Agatharchides of Cnidus in the latter’s five-volume history on this body of water. An unknown first-century Greek merchant discusses trade secrets around the Horn of Africa in a work titled for this body of water, which is associated with the modern-day Red Sea.

answers: chocolate (The Famous Artists series was produced by Cadbury.)
parts: Name this substance, boxes of which can be used to describe crowd-pleasing, overly sentimental paintings. A cup of this substance is served alongside a glass of water by a pink-bonneted maid in a Jean-Étienne Liotard pastel.

Toadstool pixies surround a child in a Cadbury design by Arthur Rackham, known for his fantastical works for this purpose. Aubrey Beardsley’s black-and-white works for this purpose include Salome holding up a dripping head.

This artist’s popular “six-footer” landscapes earned him a reputation as a chocolate-box artist. Confectionery tins often feature this artist’s painting of Willy Lott’s cottage as three horses pull the title Hay Wain across a river.

answers: disproportionation reaction [accept dismutation reaction; prompt on redox or oxidation-reduction]
hydride [or H-minus; do not accept “H” or “H-plus”]
parts: In the presence of a strong base or Lewis acid, [read slowly] a non-enolizable aldehyde can oxidize another molecule of the aldehyde to a carboxylic acid, and is itself reduced to a primary alcohol in what reaction?
The maximum yield of the primary alcohol from the Cannizzaro reaction is 50% because it is one of these reactions, in which a reagent is simultaneously oxidized and reduced.
Another way to reduce an aldehyde to a primary alcohol uses reagents that deliver this nucleophilic group. Reagents that deliver this anionic hydrogen group include DIBAL-H.

answers: The Woman Warrior: Memoirs of a Girlhood Among Ghosts
Sūn Wùkōng [accept the Monkey King; prompt on Tripmaster Monkey: His Fake Book]
parts: Name this author of the essay “Mother Tongue,” in which her mother describes this author’s novel, The Joy Luck Club, as “so easy to read.”

In this novel, the protagonist’s mother claims she cut part of her daughter’s tongue to help her speak. The protagonist’s aunt kills herself after giving birth in a pigsty in this novel’s chapter “No-Name Woman.”

Maxine Hong Kingston, who wrote The Woman Warrior, alludes to this figure in the title of a book about Wittman Ah Sing. The graphic novel American Born Chinese reimagines when this figure stole the emperor’s wine after being excluded from a divine banquet.

You first have a rabbi inspect your parchment and certify it as this status. Your thread and quill also come from animals with this designation, which also describes “clean” food products that bear an OU or K symbol.

You then go to one of these baths to purify yourself before you touch your quill, and you will return to it each time you write God’s name. Niddah, or menstruating Orthodox women, must also cleanse themselves in these baths before reassociating with their husbands.

Finally, you test your quill by writing this people’s name and crossing it out. Thus you fulfill the mitzvah of “blotting out” this people, whom the Israelites defeated at Rephidim when Aaron and Hur held up Moses’s hands.

answers: The Romance of the Rose [or Le Roman de la Rose]
parts: Name this author of The Book of Feats of Arms and Chivalry. Reason, Rectitude, and Justice help this author build the title structure in The Book of the City of Ladies.

The Book of the City of Ladies was partially written in response to Jean de Meun’s addition to this chivalric poem. At the end of this poem, Venus defeats Danger and Jealousy, allowing the Lover to pick the title flower.

Pizan likely used this author’s On Famous Women as reference material for The Book of the City of Ladies. Several Florentines who have fled the black plague tell stories in this author’s book The Decameron.

answers: Santería [or La Regla de Ocha or Lucumí]
parts: Name this bodhisattva of compassion. Images of this goddess of mercy, who often wields a willow branch and a vial of water, can also be found on altars to Oshún.
Another deity, Guān Yǔ, was syncretized as San Fancón with Saint Barbara and this orisha, whose colors are red and white. This orisha wields a double-headed ax.

Indentured Chinese laborers syncretized Guānyīn and Guān Yǔ with the orishas and saints in this Cuban religion. The U.S. Supreme Court upheld the right of adherents of this religion to sacrifice chickens.

answers: Roman Catholic Church [accept the Vatican or the Papacy or the Holy See; prompt on Christian Church or the Church]
Benito Mussolini [or Benito Amilcare Andrea Mussolini; accept Il Duce]
Gentile [accept Emilio Gentile or Giovanni Gentile]
parts: Name this organization that Pius XI administered until his death in 1939.

Kertzer titled his book for Pope Pius XI and this leader. Pius XI criticized this leader’s suppression of Catholic Youth Organizations in the “We Do Not Need” encyclical, after he recognized this leader in the Lateran Pacts.

In “Fascism as a Political Religion,” a thinker with this surname coined the term “sacralization of politics” to describe how Mussolini promoted the title construct to counter the Catholic Church’s influence in Italian society. Another thinker with this surname ghost-wrote much of Mussolini’s “The Doctrine of Fascism.”

answers: type 2 diabetes mellitus [or T2D; prompt on diabetes mellitus or DM]
parts: Name this disorder. The Indian Health Service aims to decrease metformin treatment costs for this disorder to address high rates among tribal nations in the United States.

The prevalence of food deserts, regions with little access to this type of store, in Native American reservations contributes to high rates of type 2 diabetes. There are only thirteen examples of this type of store in the Navajo Nation, including zero Krogers or Whole Foods.

This thinker linked both thrifty genes and Coca-colonization to high rates of type 2 diabetes among the Akimel O’odham (“AH-kim-uhl OH-oh-dahm”), or Pima people, in “The Double Puzzle of Diabetes.” This thinker expanded those arguments into a chapter of The World Until Yesterday.

answers: op-amps [or operational amplifiers; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name these analog circuit elements, which are symbolized by a triangle. They magnify the voltage difference between their inverting and non-inverting inputs.

Placing a capacitor in the feedback path of an op-amp creates a circuit element that performs this operation, since the magnitude of the output voltage depends on the length of time a voltage is present at the input.

Applying positive feedback to the non-inverting input of an op-amp creates a Schmitt trigger, which converts analog signals to these signals. Unlike analog signals, these signals only take on discrete values.
